The net of a right circular cylinder consists of a rectangle and
two circles. The length of the rectangle is equal to the circumference of the base, that is 2πr. Its width is the height of the cylinder h.
Some useful formulas that are used in conjunction with cylinders: • The lateral surface area of a right circular cylinder is equal to the circumference of the base times the height, h, of the cylinder: LA = 2πrh. • The total surface area of a right circular cylinder is the sum of the lateral area and 2 twice the area, B, of one of the circles: TA = 2πrh + 2B = 2πrh + 2πr . • The volume of a right circular cylinder is equal to the area of a base times the 2 height of the cylinder: V = πr h.
Important The volume of a solid with the same cross-sectional area at all levels is the product of the area of the base and its height. The lateral surface area of a solid with the same cross-sectional area at all levels is the product of the perimeter of the base and its height.
